title: Overall Neuropathy Limitations Scale (ONLS)
description: Quantifies the severity of functional disability in peripheral neuropathy by assessing upper and lower extremity functional activities. This validated scale is widely used to track disease progression and treatment response in various neuropathic conditions, particularly immune-mediated polyneuropathies.

parameters.name: arms_grade
parameters.description: Arms functional disability grade based on ability to perform arm and hand functions

scoring.1: Minor symptoms or signs in arms, not affecting function
scoring.2: Mild disability in arms affecting but not preventing function
scoring.3: Moderate disability in arms preventing at least one function but not preventing all functions
scoring.4: Severe disability in both arms preventing all functions, but some purposeful movements remain possible
scoring.5: Arms disability preventing all purposeful movements

parameters.name: legs_grade
parameters.description: Legs functional disability grade based on walking ability, climbing stairs, and running capacity

scoring.0: Walking, climbing stairs, and running not affected
scoring.1: Walking, climbing stairs, and running affected but able to walk normally
scoring.2: Walks independently, but with abnormal gait
scoring.3: Requires unilateral support (cane, crutch, wall) to walk 10 meters
scoring.4: Requires bilateral support (walker, crutches, or two people) to walk 10 meters
scoring.5: Wheelchair bound, but able to stand and walk 1 meter with help
scoring.6: Restricted to wheelchair, some purposeful leg movements possible
scoring.7: Restricted to wheelchair or bed, no purposeful leg movements

result.name: onls_total_score
result.description: Total ONLS score representing overall neuropathy severity and functional limitations

ranges.interpretation: Normal function in both arms and legs with no evidence of functional disability from peripheral neuropathy.
Mild peripheral neuropathy with minimal impact on daily activities. Some symptoms present but function largely preserved.
Moderate peripheral neuropathy with noticeable impact on daily activities. May require assistive devices or modifications.
Severe peripheral neuropathy with substantial functional impairment requiring significant assistance or adaptive equipment.
Very severe peripheral neuropathy with profound disability requiring extensive care and assistance for most activities.

references: Graham RC, Hughes RA. A modified peripheral neuropathy scale: the Overall Neuropathy Limitations Scale. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2006;77(8):973-6. doi: 10.1136/jnnp.2005.081547.

Hughes RA, Donofrio P, Bril V, Dalakas MC, Deng C, Hanna K, et al. Intravenous immune globulin (10% caprylate-chromatography purified) for the treatment of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (ICE study): a randomised placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Neurol. 2008;7(2):136-44. doi: 10.1016/S1474-4422(07)70329-0.

van Nes SI, Vanhoutte EK, van Doorn PA, Hermans M, Bakkers M, Kuitwaard K, et al. Rasch-built Overall Disability Scale (R-ODS) for immune-mediated peripheral neuropathies. Neurology. 2011;76(4):337-45. doi: 10.1212/WNL.0b013e318208824b.
formula: ONLS Total Score = Arms Grade (0-5) + Legs Grade (0-7)
notes: The ONLS is a modified version of the Overall Disability Sum Score (ODSS) with better content validity and reduced ceiling effect
Originally validated in 100 patients with various peripheral nerve disorders
High inter-rater reliability with intraclass correlation coefficient of 0.97
Acceptable responsiveness with standardized response mean of 0.76
Best used with direct patient observation rather than patient self-reporting
Not validated for use in pediatric populations
Particularly useful for tracking progression in immune-mediated polyneuropathies
The legs scale includes running and stair climbing to reduce ceiling effects compared to ODSS
Should be used in conjunction with other neuropathy assessment tools for comprehensive evaluation
Scores of 0-3 generally indicate preserved independence in daily activities
Scores â‰¥7 typically indicate need for mobility aids or assistance
Regular monitoring can help assess treatment response and disease progression
